title: What are some of the best bands that feature two lead singers? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first obvious answer is the Beatles. John Lennon and Paul McCartney shared songwriting and singing duties virtually equally. And lead guitarist George Harrison was a prolific songwriter and singer in his own right writing and singing lead on several Beatles songs including “Something,” “While My Guitar Gently Weeps,” “Taxman,” “Here Comes the Sun,” “I, Me, Mine,” and “Within You Without You,” just to name a few. Finally, Ringo Starr famously sang “Yellow Submarine” along with “Octopus’s Garden” and “With a Little Help From My Friends.” Fleetwood Mac has had several lead singers beginning with Peter Green way back in the late 60’s when they formed as a pop-blues band in London. Of course the popular Fleetwood Mac lineup of the 70s and 80s included Stevie Nicks, Lindsey Buckingham, and Christine McVie on lead vocals on various tracks. A band that is certainly under-appreciated but has had a widespread influence on the Brit-pop scene is XTC. They began in the late 1970s as sort of a power pop outfit, but were definitely more New Wave than anything. They have spanned several decades, and their lead singers Andy Partridge and Colin Moulding also shared the song writing. I put them higher up in this list simply because they have been a favorite of mine for years, and absolutely deserve a wider audience. And then there’s Pink Floyd. Original lead singer Syd Barrett fronted the group from 1965 until 1969 when he left the band due to mental health issues. But even during that time, founding members Roger Waters and Richard Wright also sang. Then David Gilmour jointed in 1967, and was the main lead on most albums. But of course Waters led on many tracks as well. We also can't forget the Eagles. Glenn Frey and Don Henley are widely considered to be the main lead singers, but let’s not forget that Joe Walsh also sang and went on to have a successful solo career, as did Frey and Henley. Randy Meisner, Don Felder, Bernie Leadon, and Timothy B. Schmit all deserve a mention, though they would hardly be considered frontmen when it came to the Eagles. The Beach Boys had creative genius Brian Wilson as their defacto leader. But lead singing duties were generally given to Mike Love. Wilson sang lead on many of the ballads along with his brother Carl. Al Jardine and Dennis Wilson sang lead on many of the bands more upbeat tunes. I was surprised to learn long ago that The Cars actually featured two lead singers. I had assumed Ric Okasec sing lead on all of The Cars songs for years. In fact, bassist Benjamin Orr sang lead on some of their most famous tracks, including “Just What I Needed,” “Drive,” “It’s All I Can Do,” “Bye Bye Love,” “Let’s Go,” and one of my favorites, “Moving In Stereo.” I could probably go on and on with this list to include bands like: The Grateful Dead (Jerry Garcia & Bob Weir), The Band (Levon Helm, Richard Manuel, & Rick Danko) ZZ Top (Dusty Hill & Billy Gibbons)The Clash (Joe Strummer & Mick Jones)The Monkees (Davey Jones, Mickey Dolenz, & Mike Nesmith)KISS (Paul Stanley & Gene Simmons)Styx (Dennis DeYoung & Tommy Shaw)Hüsker Dü (Bob Mould & Grant Hart)Sonic Youth (Thurston Moore, Kim Gordon, & Lee Ranaldo)Fugazi (Ian MacKaye & Guy Picciotto)The B-52’s (Fred Schneider, Cindy Wilson, & Kate Pierson)Alice In Chains (Layne Staley & Jerry Cantrell)Alkaline Trio (Matt Skiba & Dan Andriano)Linkin Park (Chester Bennington & Mike Shinoda)Good Charlotte (Joel & Benji Madden)Mastodon (Brann Dailor, Brent Hinds, & Troy Sanders) Finally, it could be argued that Oasis had two lead singers in brothers Liam and Noel Gallagher. Liam was certainly considered the lead singer, but on more than one occasion when the mood struck him, Liam would decide not to perform and Noel would step in flawlessly. After breaking up, both bothers went on to form new bands independent of one another. Liam fronted Beady Eye before going solo, and Noel formed Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds, who are still active.

A fair ol’ range to choose from, so I’ll list just a few that feature on my music collection: ABBA (Agnetha Faltskog & Frida Lyngstad, plus the odd lead turn from guitarist Bjorn Ulvaeus)Alphabeat (Anders Stig Gehrt Nielsen and Stina Bramsen)Level 42 (Mark King & Mike Lindup)The Cars (Ben Orr & Ric Ocasek)Oasis (mostly Liam Gallagher but some songs had brother Noel on lead vocals)Fleetwood Mac (Stevie Nicks, Lyndsey Buckingham and Christine McVie)UB40 (Duncan & Robin Campbell, plus brother Ali prior to his departure)The Beatles (Paul McCartney & John Lennon primarily, but the other pair also had turns on lead vox)Toto (David Paich, Bobby Kimball, Joseph Williams et al)The B-52s (Cindy Wilson, Kate Pierson, Fred Schneider)The Beat (Dave Wakeling, Ranking Roger)Ladytron (Helen Marnie & Mira Aroyo)Mike & The Mechanics (Andrew Roachford & Tim Howar; formerly Paul Carrack and Paul Young)XTC (Andy Partridge & Colin Moulding)Roxette (Marie Fredriksson & Per Gessle)Scissor Sisters (Jake Shears & Ana Matronic)Squeeze (Chris Difford & Glen Tilbrook)Stranglers (Hugh Cornwell & J.J Burnel)Supertramp (Rick Davies and Roger Hodgson)Pink Floyd (David Gilmour & Roger Waters)Eagles (Don Henley & Glenn Frey plus the odd song featuring Joe Walsh)

Anything which comes up with more than one vocalist, Beatles makes on the list. They didn’t have two but three great lead singers. Ringo was good too but John, Paul and George had remarkable vocal skills. Especially John and Paul. Another great band I could think of is Fleetwood Mac with having two prominent lovers and singers ;) I could also mention The Band, with having three great singers Levon, Manuel and Rick. Robbie also had great vocal skills. Queen on the other hand I have to mention. Even though they typically weren’t lead vocals, but along with Freddie, Roger Taylor had tremendous vocal skills. Brian May too had good vocals. But have to admit that Roger had almost same skills as Freddie. Cream also had two lead singers - Jack Bruce and Eric Clapton. The Byrds also. Blink 182 also had great singers - Tom Delonge and Mark Hoppus. Deep Purple also with Mark III and IV had two singers - Glenn and Coverdale. That all I could think off. By the way, thanks for the a2a :)

There are lots of great bands that feature two singers who work as a duo. They often sing close or tight harmony, like the Everly Brothers or the Bee Gees. The Beatles had two of the greatest rock singers of all time in the same band and they used their duo talents generously and brilliantly over the years. They were possibly the greatest rock harmony group. However, I have another favorite I want to mention. I always enjoyed the vocal approach of The Jefferson Airplane when Marty Balin and Grace Slick shared lead vocals. Their voices were distinct, and they didn’t really harmonize as much as they interwove their vocals, alternating, singing over each other, and sharing the vocal space as equals. It created a great effect and was completely original. I thought it was great. YMMV.

Besides explicit duos like The Everly Brothers and Simon and Garfunkel, and excluding 3, 4, and 5 member vocal groups like the Platters and Crosby, Stills, Nash, and Young, several great two-lead-singer bands come to mind: The Beatles count, though George and Ringo each had some tunes, too. The Los Angeles Punk band X should count - the twining, keening mix of Exene Cervenka and John Doe are almost constantly battling for the spotlight on songs like “We’re Desperate” and “Johny Hit and Run Paulene”. Various incarnations of Jefferson Airplane and Jefferson Starship and Starship usually had two singers in the front: Grace Slick and Paul Kantner, Grace and Marty Balin, Grace and Mickey Thomas. Three Dog Night had three through their greatest era, as did Fleetwood Mac. Weir and Garcia threw it back and forth a lot in the Grateful Dead. I don’t know if there have been many in this century, though…

Well I am a Heavy Metal fan/Goth so that will be my focus for this particular question. My first focus will be Doom/Gothic/Symphonic metal bands I enjoy to include:  Lacuna Coil  Epica  Draconian  Sirenia  and Battlelore (which is a hybrid of genres) Additionally you have Melodic Black Metal bands (sure you could argue they are not true to “two vocalists” but more or less backup but still I will add them) that have two vocalists depending on the songs.  Chthonic  Cradle of Filth  Siebenburgen  Also Sojourner who are pretty much folk black metal. Those are just a handful of examples in heavy metal…additionally in the more “Gothic” realm of things there are these groups:  Blutengel who play a dark synthpop style  Ashbury Heights  Suicidal Romance  In Strict Confidence (no the goat is not one of the singers LOL)  A true Goth rock band: AoL sometimes fused vocals although Voe was their main vocalist RIP  Mephisto Walz is another good Goth Rock example So yeah these are some of my personal favorites for two vocalists.

There aren’t too many good examples but I can think of two excellent ones: the first is Abba where the two girls harmonised and created quite a specific sound that became their trademark. Very appealing and attractive to hear. Second I would mention Fleetwood Mac with Stevie Nicks and Lindsey Buckingham. They played off each other very effectively, and we can even add a third singer in the form of Christine McVie in that particular band. Generally though it’s not something one sees too much. Another example is The B52s, like a weird alternative version of Abba, the two girls dovetailed nicely although like Fleetwood Mac they had a third singer in the form of Fred Schneider.

The Beatles, for one. John Lennon and Paul McCartney each sang a lot of the band’s songs. However, George Harrison and Ringo Starr both had songs of their own as well. The one I prefer though is KISS. Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons alternate between songs most of the time. Gene sings the more pervy or evil-sounding songs, while Paul does their more rock/pop-oriented ones. However, like the Beatles, KISS’s other members, currently Tommy Thayer and Eric Singer, have been known to sing lead on occasion.

It does happen from time to time. The Cars: Ric Ocassic sang most of the leads but Benjamin Orr had a few leadsPink Floyd: Roger Waters, David Gilmour and sometimes Rick Wright.The Beatles: All four sang leadTemptations: Eddie Kendrick and David Ruffin during the classic era.Rolling Stones: Yes, mostly Mick Jagger but Keith Richards sang a couple of good leads.Hall and Oates: Both have sang lead.The Monkees: Everyone sang.Mamas and Papas: All sang.

I will try and avoid those already mentioned and suggest the band that included Otis Williams, David Ruffin and Eddie Kendricks. All great singers who contributed to “The Temptations” Funnily enough the band I’m playing in the background had two lead singers, unfortunately both departed, Pete Ham and Tom Evans from the very under-rated “Badfinger”. Sadly only Otis Williams is still alive of those singers I’ve mentioned, better quit this Aimone, tastes great but makes me morose.

I loved the Reivers quite a bit. They had two lead vocalists: John Croslin and Kim Longacre. In their initial active period, they released an EP and five studio albums from 1984 to 1991. Here’s the cover of their debut album, Translate Slowly, originally released under their initial band name, Zeitgeist, in 1985, but remixed and re-released in 1988 under the Reivers name:
Just two? The Cars, Cream, Blue Oyster Cult. But several bands had more than two: the Beatles, Fleetwood Mac, the Eagles, Chicago, the Moody Blues.
Kiss have two lead singers, Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons, when they first started back in the 70’s all four members sang lead, Ace Frehley and Peter Criss have since been replaced

Some examples of TWO lead singers : Everly Brothers , Rank And File, Wire, Sam And Dave,Grateful Dead , X, Sonny And Cher, Faces, Mott The Hoople THREE: Jefferson Airplane, Sonic Youth ,Crosby, Stills, and Nash FOUR: Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young, Beatles, Mamas And Papas ..and definitely more examples of all of these are out there !

Depends what era..In the 90d you had Shakespeare's sister…I really liked them..80s had 2 sisters really bad…Then there's the cheeky girls..lol…You're actually best to Google..OH…Bacara..70s or early 80s…yes sir I can boogie ,❤️❤️love that so much…Yeah..so much easier to Google.👌Edit…I missread this as two female singers…walker brothers? As I said..you're best to Google.

From its inception, Bachman-Turner Overdrive had two lead singers, mainly guitarist Randy Bachman and bassist Fred Turner. Another Bachman brother named Tim - who also played guitar - contributed lead vocals to a few tracks until he left after their second album. When Randy left and was replaced by ex-April Wine bassist Jim Clench, Jim also took up lead vocals.
Your question is adorable that reminds me right away to my legendary KISS with the dual: Paul Stanley & Gene Simmons. For 51 years but they still rocked. Vote for ‘em!! 🤘🤘
The Cars with Rick Ocasak and Ben Orr Pink Floyd with Dave Gilmore and Roger Waters the Beatles had John, Paul, and George the Eagles Triumph

In 1974/75 deep purple had David Coverdale and Glenn Hughes. I once saw a prog black Metal band called Tristania who had 3 vocalists. A male trad ‘rock’ singer, a female opera singer and a death metal style crowler. Interesting. I suppose you could say ‘KISS’ have 2 singers in Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley. Also Styx and Chicago.

One that come to mind was Johnny & Edgar Winter or Johnny Winter and Rick Derringer. Also, The Beach Boys,The Persuasions, Earth, Wind and Fire, The Righteous Bros. Simon & Garfunkel, Doobie Bros. and many accapella and soul bands.

The Beatles - Haven't read the other answers but i'm pretty sure everybody mentioned them… KISS also comes to mind. The B 52″s - in this case the lead singers sing most songs together instead of alternately
Three Dog Night had 3 lead singers( Cory Wells,Danny Hutton,& Chuck Negron). Although they were a cover band they did the cover songs very well and made them their own…..

The Who - all four members could sing, but Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend sang most of the lead vocals, although bassist John Entwistle was quite a gifted singer as well. A Quick One (While He’s Away) (1968):
